utterances: Barrel bombs, chemical weapons, starvation as a weapon of war.
These are just some of the atrocities that are being documented each day in Syria, according to U.S.
Ambassador Samantha Power.
Sadly, because of the decision of the Russian Federation to back the Syrian regime no matter what it does, the Syrian people will not see justice today.
They will see crime but not punishment.
She says the Security Council was briefed recently on the tens of thousands of photos, provided by a Syrian defector, of corpses showing signs of starvation and torture.
These photos shock and horrify, even after some of us wondered if there was anything the regime could do could still shock.
Power suggested that history books should show those pictures of emaciated corpses, next to pictures of the two diplomats who - in her words - prevented justice for the victims.
Our grandchildren will ask us years from now, how we could have failed to bring justice to people living in Hell on Earth.
Russia's Ambassador Vitaly Churkin, wasn't moved, calling those photos by the defector: unconfirmed and unverifiable, and arguing that those who were pushing for the U.N.
resolution are really looking for a pretext to armed intervention.
Churkin is calling for local truces, like the one in the city of Homs, which was recently retaken by government forces.
(Through Translator) One cannot but recall a Russian saying: A bad peace is better than a good quarrel.
And what our Western colleagues proposing instead: talk, good for naive people, that they will be providing new types of weapons to good opposition groups only.
The French Ambassador Gerard Araud, who drafted the resolution, calls this a sad day when Russia covers up crimes with its veto and then spouts invective against other council members.
(Through Translator) It's called Chutzpah in New York.
the West is accused of providing weapons to the opposition, when Russia has never stopped providing weapons to the regime.

Though it was a day of high diplomatic drama, the Security Council remains on the sidelines of the war in Syria, which is heading into elections likely to give Syrian president Bashar al-Assad another seven-year term.
Diplomats may try again next week to press for humanitarian access.
A resolution calling for that was approved earlier this year, but aid workers say millions of Syrians remain out of reach to them and civilian areas are still targeted with barrel bombs.
France's Ambassador Araud isn't sounding very hopeful.
There is a moment where suddenly you realize that, you know, you are powerless in front of barbarians and their supporters.
Poem and verse.
I think you almost need a psychologist to answer that question because in many ways it is a very antisocial game.
You know, it allows you to do things in a game that if you actually tried to do in the real world you'd be standing in front of a judge being sentenced to 15 to 20.
That explains why the game is so controversial, which may also add to its appeal for some people.
That's kind of illicit appeal.
Right.
So, 400 million dollars its opening week?
How many copies is it expected to sell?

Well, the game comes out April 29th, but fans have been placing orders in advance for months and based on those presales and orders from retailers, Daily Variety reported this week that the game could sell more than six million copies in its first week which adds up that 400 million dollar figure and would be a new record.
So, a new record, yeah.
What's the current record holder?
That would be a game called Halo 3, which Microsoft makes.
It brought in 300 million dollars in its first week.
But it's only available for its Xbox 360 system.
GTA 4 has versions for both Xbox and PlayStation.
So, it could have a much wider reach.
And there's another business story to this story that we should talk about.
Because this company, the company that makes Grand Theft Auto, it's involved in a takeover battle.
A nasty takeover battle, right?
It is.
Yes.

A company called Take Two Interactive publishes and distributes Grand Theft Auto and it's been fending off a two billion dollar hostile takeover offer from one of the largest video game publishers, Electronic Arts.
Take Two actually holds its annual shareholder meeting this evening and it's expected to be pretty contentious.
Some shareholders apparently want this deal to go forward.
Electronic Arts is a much bigger company with more resources and the Take Two board is going to have to justify why they've turned down the offer.
And they'll no doubt be using the success of Grand Theft Auto 4 as one justification for that.
No doubt.
Thank you Amy.
That is Amy Scott of public radio's daily business show, Marketplace.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Tony Cox in Washington.
Next year, women will be able to get birth control without co-pays or deductibles.
The Obama administration on Monday accepted the recommendations of the Institute of Medicine that birth control and several other procedures, like HIV screening, be treated as preventive medicine.
The administration says it's trying to eliminate the cost barrier to birth control that some women face today.
It is a shift in policy and for some a confusing one at that.
We have been hearing for days now about free birth control.
We want to answer some of your questions about the changes that may affect you.
Will this change affect whether or how you get birth control?
What do you think the impact will be?
The email address is talk@npr.org.
And you can join the conversation at our website.
Go to npr.org, and click on TALK OF THE NATION.
In a few moments, we'll hear from Dr. Linda Rosenstock, who chaired the committee that recommended the change.
And we'll also talk to law professor Helen Alvare about religious exemptions from the ruling.
First, though, we are joined now by NPR health policy correspondent Julie Rovner.
She's with us here in Studio 3A.
Julie, thanks for dropping by.
My pleasure.
To be clear, let's start with this.
This isn't exactly the free birth control that some headlines have been advertising.
No, it's not.
It's really - first of all, it's only for people who have health insurance.
It just means that you'll be paying for it as part of your premium rather than as you go, and so there will be no deductibles, no co-pays.

It will make it easier to get, and hopefully, according to this Institute of Medicine panel that recommended it, it will, as you've mentioned, take away some of the cost barriers at the time of usage to encourage more people to use it.
It's one of these many preventive care services that last year's health law is trying to encourage people to use.
The law actually stipulated, right within the law, several types of preventive care services that it wanted to encourage people to get more of.
So it wrote those into the law.
Now, there was an amendment by Senator Barbara Mikulski of Maryland suggesting that there were some women's health services that had not been added to the list, perhaps as they should have been.
So it encouraged the Department of Health and Human Services to add those.

The Department of Health and Human Services in turn asked the Institute of Medicine to look at which women's health services had enough of an evidence base to be added to this list, and there was this list of eight services, of which contraception was one.
And obviously that is the lightning rod issue among those eight.
But what are some of the other ones?
Some of the other ones are more support for breastfeeding, including rental of breast pumps.
As you mentioned, screening for sexually transmitted diseases, including HIV, and annual well-woman visit.
That's something that right now a lot of women have to pay a co-pay for, and so therefore a lot of women don't get, and that's the key to a lot of these other services.
If you can't go for an annual visit, perhaps you don't get that free Pap smear or that free mammogram.
So if you can't go for that annual visit, if you don't have the money to pay for that annual visit, you might not get some of these other, quote-unquote, free services.
Now these services that we are talking about, they only affect women who already have health insurance.
Is that correct?
That's right and not even perhaps all of those.
These only apply - and this is one of the confusing things about the health law - these only apply to new plans and plans that are not quote-unquote grandfathered.
So if you had a plan that was in effect on the date the law was signed, which was March 23rd of 2010, it might not affect your plan until that plan changes.
So as plans add or drop benefits or change their premiums dramatically, then until that happens, they are considered grandfathered.
So the people who are - your employer or your insurer, depending on who you're getting the plan from - don't have to add these benefits until they are no longer grandfathered.
#NAME?
Conman and writer - not two career choices I would likely put together - but James Magnuson's new novel, ""Famous Writers I Have Known,"" does just that.
Director of the University of Texas's writing program, Magnuson knows a thing or two about teaching his craft.
Our reviewer, Alan Cheuse, delves into Magnuson's new satirical comedy, which he calls a delightful take on writing programs and American life.

On the run from some vengeful New York mobsters, conman Frankie Abandonato, in a neat plot twist right up front, hides in plain sight down in Austin, Texas, posing as one of America's most lauded and secretive writers, a novelist appropriately named V.S.
Mohle - sort of a Salinger stand-in.

For a number of months, Abandonato scams a lot of people in the writing world: the director of the writing center at the University of Texas - not the author of this novel, of course, but a sort of pathetic doppelganger of same - and the bestselling novelist in decline who's underwritten a lot of the Texas program - a sort of pathetic doppelganger of the late James Michener - and an elite cadre of worshipful fiction students who place themselves at his feet.

Abandonato treats them all to his version of a great novelist, winging it every day, with a little help from some instructive articles and his conman instincts, producing sweet comedy for us as readers as he goes.
We work in the dark, he mulls over Henry James's famous dictum about writing fiction.
We do what we can.
Now, what that meant, he admits, I had no clue.
The only people I knew who worked in the dark were cat burglars and heating duct repairmen.
Before his scheme begins, as it must, to fall apart, Frankie does learn something important about the life of a writer.
This whole writing thing was worse than heroin, he observes.
The story he tells of his unusual and comic and sweetly told caper will be addictive in itself for all passionate writers and readers.
The novel is ""Famous Writer I Have Known"" by James Magnuson.
Our reviewer is Alan Cheuse.
NPR's business news starts with a vote on jobs for veterans.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
As so often happens, this next story brings to mind a report from the satirical newspaper, The Onion.

A recent Onion headline reads: ""Obama Now Attempting to get Each Word of Jobs Bill Passed Individually."" It's not quite that bad, but the Senate will vote this afternoon on a small part of the president's jobs plan.
This measure is aimed at getting unemployed veterans to work by providing tax credits of up to $9,600 to companies that hire disabled vets.
The bill is expected to pass the Senate by a wide bipartisan margin - just a day before the country observes Veterans Day.
A vote by the House is expected early next week.
